m_DescList: JSON is a lightweight data interchange format widely used for data storage and transmission.
Data consists of key-value pairs. Keys must be strings, while values can be strings, numbers, Booleans, arrays, objects, or null.
For example, the following demonstrates a JSON snippet:
The outermost layer is a pair of symmetrical <color=#3c3cff>{ }</color>.
Notably, the outermost symmetrical <color=#3c3cff>{ }</color> represents an object. In the example, matching braces share the same color coding.
Objects and arrays can continue nesting strings, numbers, Booleans, arrays, objects, or null following the same format.
Since <color=#33aa55>[ ]</color>, <color=#3c3cff>{ }</color>, and <color=#ee3300>" "</color> appear in pairs, balancing groups can be used to simply validate JSON data legality.
To simplify the problem, the following conventions apply:
1. Only perform basic pair counting, without complex format checks.
*Example: { "key": [, "key2": ] } passes balancing group checks despite formatting errors.*
2. Symbols inside strings like <color=#ee3300>"[]{}"</color> are ignored for balancing group counts.
3. Prioritize solution-oriented programming—passing test cases suffices. No need for 100% JSON-validation regex.
<color=#666666>This problem is quite difficult—skip if needed...</color>
Construct a regex to pass all test cases on the right.
